deliberation: Considered whether 'hand' and 'ear' of YHWH are literal or anthropomorphic metaphors. In prophetic style these are standard bodily metaphors for power and attentiveness. Two parallel but distinct images: shortened hand (inability to save) and heavy ear (inability to hear).

instances.english_text: GOD’s arm is not too short to save
vehicle: a shortened arm/hand that cannot reach
posture: asserting that God is not limited
instances.explanation: God’s saving power is described in terms of a human arm that might be too short to reach; a bodily image (hand) stands metonymically for effective power.

instances.english_text: Or ear too dull to hear
vehicle: a heavy/dull ear that cannot hear
ground: ability or inability to perceive pleas
instances.explanation: God’s responsiveness is depicted as if he had an ‘ear’ that might be too heavy to hear, a bodily organ standing for the act of listening.

deliberation: Looked for metaphorical description of the effect of sin. Found (1) sins as a separating barrier between people and God, and (2) the idiomatic metaphor of God’s face being hidden, for withdrawal of favor and refusal to hear.

instances.hebrew_text: עֲוֹנֹתֵיכֶם הָיוּ מַבְדִּלִים בֵּינֵכֶם לְבֵין אֱלֹהֵיכֶם
instances.english_text: your iniquities have been a barrier between you and your God
target: The relational rupture caused by sin
posture: warning about the relational cost of sin
instances.explanation: The verse depicts iniquities as if they were a physical barrier standing between the people and God, conveying spiritual distance through spatial imagery.

instances.english_text: Your sins have turned the divine face away in refusal to hear you
target: God’s withdrawal of favor and attention
vehicle: a face being hidden or turned away
ground: turning one’s face away signals refusal and displeasure
posture: portrays God as justly refusing to heed
instances.explanation: The idiom of God ‘hiding his face’ uses facial orientation as a metonym for favor and attention; sins cause God to avert his ‘face,’ i.e., to refuse to hear.

deliberation: Examined whether the blood and body parts are literal or figurative. The verse uses hands, fingers, lips, and tongue to stand for the people’s actions and speech, a synecdoche/metonymy rather than simple literal anatomy.

instances.hebrew_text: כַפֵּיכֶם נְגֹאֲלוּ בַדָּם וְאֶצְבְּעוֹתֵיכֶם בֶּעָוֹן שִׂפְתֹתֵיכֶם דִּבְּרוּ־שֶׁקֶר לְשׁוֹנְכֶם עַוְלָה תֶהְגֶּה
instances.english_text: your hands are defiled with crime and your fingers with iniquity; your lips speak falsehood, your tongue utters treachery
target: The whole person’s violent and deceitful behavior
vehicle: hands, fingers, lips, tongue stained or active in wrongdoing
ground: bodily members are the instruments of action and speech
expression of inward character through outward members
instances.explanation: Hands/fingers/lips/tongue function as synecdoche and metonymy for the people’s violent deeds and deceitful speech, portraying guilt as if inscribed on their very members.

deliberation: Looked for non-literal expressions. The core figurative element is the pregnancy/birth metaphor: conceiving mischief and giving birth to iniquity, describing the origin and outcome of evil as gestation.

instances.english_text: Conceiving wrong and begetting evil
target: The planning and execution of wicked schemes
vehicle: conception and birth of a child
ground: hidden beginning leading to inevitable, visible result
development from small start to full outcome
posture: emphasizing how evil is intentionally nurtured
instances.explanation: Plotting evil is portrayed as conceiving and giving birth, suggesting deliberate nurturing of wrongdoing that inevitably issues in manifest iniquity.

deliberation: Verse piles up vivid images. Distinct metaphors: (1) hatching adder’s eggs for bringing forth deadly schemes; (2) weaving spider webs for spinning fragile yet harmful intrigues. Both depict the outcome and nature of their plans.

instances.hebrew_text: בֵּיצֵי צִפְעוֹנִי בִּקֵּעוּ ... הָאֹכֵל מִבֵּיצֵיהֶם יָמוּת וְהַזּוּרֶה תִּבָּקַע אֶפְעֶה
instances.english_text: They hatch adder’s eggs ... Whoever eats of those eggs will die, and if one is crushed, it hatches out a viper
target: Their wicked plans and their effects on others
vehicle: adder’s eggs that kill when eaten and become vipers when crushed
ground: their schemes are intrinsically deadly, whatever one does with them
hidden danger in seemingly small things
posture: denouncing the lethal nature of their plotting
instances.explanation: The people’s schemes are likened to snake eggs whose every use results in death; the metaphor stresses that their plans are inherently and unavoidably destructive.

instances.english_text: And weave spider webs
target: Their attempts to build security or schemes of deceit
ground: intricate yet fragile and useless as real covering
ability to ensnare but not protect
posture: exposing the futility and deceitfulness of their efforts
instances.explanation: Their works are compared to spider webs, intricate but fragile, highlighting the deceptive and ultimately useless character of their efforts.

deliberation: Continues the web imagery. Distinct figures: (1) webs as garments that cannot clothe—metaphor for futile attempts to cover themselves with their deeds; (2) ‘violence is in their hands’ uses ‘hands’ metonymically for their concrete violent actions.

instances.hebrew_text: קֻורֵיהֶם לֹא־יִהְיוּ לְבֶגֶד וְלֹא יִתְכַּסּוּ בְּמַעֲשֵׂיהֶם
instances.english_text: Their webs will not serve as a garment, what they make cannot serve as clothing
target: Their supposed moral or social ‘covering’ from their works
vehicle: garments or clothing that cover the body
ground: just as webs cannot function as real clothing, their deeds cannot provide real protection or justification
posture: undermining their confidence in their own works
instances.explanation: Their deeds are implicitly likened to spider webs that cannot become garments, stressing that their supposed protections or merits are flimsy and ineffective.

instances.english_text: Their hands commit lawless acts
vehicle: hands as the locus of action
ground: hands perform deeds and so can represent a person’s actions
posture: highlighting the tangible, physical nature of their violence
instances.explanation: ‘Hands’ functions as a metonymy/synecdoche for the people themselves in the act of doing violence, making their guilt vivid and concrete.

deliberation: Searched for bodily or path imagery. Found (1) ‘feet run to evil’ as a body-part-for-agent image depicting eagerness to do wrong, and (2) ‘destruction and injury are in their roads’—paths as metaphor for the course of life saturated with violence.

instances.hebrew_text: רַגְלֵיהֶם לָרַע יָרֻצוּ וִימַהֲרוּ לִשְׁפֹּךְ דָּם נָקִי
instances.english_text: Their feet run after evil, they hasten to shed the blood of the innocent
target: Their eagerness and swift readiness to do evil
ground: speed of feet expresses eagerness and intent
posture: emphasizing the zeal with which they pursue wrongdoing
instances.explanation: Feet are a metonym for the whole person’s movement; describing them as running to evil depicts their active, eager pursuit of wrongdoing.

instances.english_text: Destructiveness and injury are on their roads
target: The habitual course of their life and society
ground: a road represents a way of life or habitual course; these are filled with ruin
posture: depicting their whole way of life as destructive
instances.explanation: Their ‘roads’ metaphorically denote their ways of living; those ways are characterized by ruin and destruction that accompany them wherever they go.

deliberation: The verse is dominated by ‘way/path’ language for conduct. Considered whether to break into many; decided it is one extended path metaphor: moral integrity and justice as a way or path, which they make crooked and in which no one finds peace.

instances.hebrew_text: דֶּרֶךְ שָׁלוֹם לֹא יָדָעוּ וְאֵין מִשְׁפָּט בְּמַעְגְּלוֹתָם נְתִיבוֹתֵיהֶם עִקְּשׁוּ לָהֶם כֹּל דֹּרֵךְ בָּהּ לֹא יָדַע שָׁלוֹם
instances.english_text: They do not care for the way of integrity, there is no justice on their paths. They make their courses crooked, no one who walks in them cares for integrity.
target: Their moral conduct and social practice
vehicle: way, paths, courses that can be straight or crooked and walked in
ground: conduct is like traveling along a path, which can be straight/peaceful or crooked/unjust
posture: condemning their chosen ‘route’ in life as hostile to peace
instances.explanation: Abstract qualities (peace, justice) and behavior are cast as a ‘way’ or ‘paths’ that one walks, a standard metaphor for patterns of life in Hebrew thought.

deliberation: Detected two main figurative clusters: (1) justice and righteousness portrayed with spatial language (far, not reaching) that borders on personification; (2) the light/darkness imagery for salvation versus distress.

instances.hebrew_text: עַל־כֵּן רָחַק מִשְׁפָּט מִמֶּנוּ וְלֹא תַשִּׂיגֵנוּ צְדָקָה
instances.english_text: That is why redress is far from us, and vindication does not reach us
target: The experience of justice and vindication
vehicle: things or persons that are spatially far away and do not reach someone
ground: distance and failure to reach signify inaccessibility and absence
instances.explanation: Justice and righteousness are spoken of as if they were entities that could be far away or fail to catch up, lightly personifying them via spatial and pursuit language.

instances.hebrew_text: נְקַוֶּה לָאוֹר וְהִנֵּה־חֹשֶׁךְ לִנְגֹהוֹת בָּאֲפֵלוֹת נְהַלֵּךְ
instances.english_text: We hope for light, and lo! there is darkness; for a gleam, and we must walk in gloom
target: Expectation of deliverance and the actual condition of oppression/confusion
vehicle: light, brightness, darkness, gloom, and walking in them
ground: light suggests clarity, joy, and salvation; darkness suggests confusion, danger, and distress
ability/inability to see and move safely
posture: expressing deep lament over the reversal of expectations
instances.explanation: The terms ‘light’ and ‘darkness’ are metaphors for hoped-for deliverance versus actual calamity, and ‘walking in gloom’ depicts living under ongoing affliction.

deliberation: This verse is a chain of similes: (1) groping like the blind/without eyes; (2) stumbling at noon as if at twilight; (3) being like the dead among the robust. Each comparison has a distinct image and ground.

instances.hebrew_text: נְגַשְׁשָׁה כַּעִוְרִים קִיר וּכְאֵין עֵינַיִם נְגַשֵּׁשָׁה
instances.english_text: We grope, like the blind along a wall; like those without eyes we grope
target: Their moral and spiritual confusion and helplessness
vehicle: blind people groping along a wall, those without eyes seeking their way
ground: inability to see one’s way and need to feel along speaks to disorientation and vulnerability
instances.explanation: Their condition under judgment is likened to blind persons feeling their way along a wall, capturing extreme disorientation and vulnerability.

instances.english_text: We stumble at noon, as if in darkness
target: Their inability to function even when conditions should favor them
vehicle: people stumbling at noon as if it were dusk/twilight
ground: stumbling in broad daylight suggests abnormal, intensified blindness or confusion
posture: heightening the sense of abnormal calamity
instances.explanation: They are compared to people who stumble at mid-day as though it were dark, a simile emphasizing how deep their confusion is despite ‘daylight’ conditions.

instances.english_text: Among the sturdy, we are like the dead
target: Their weakness and near-ruin compared to others’ apparent vigor
vehicle: dead people among the fat/sturdy ones
ground: deadness signifies complete incapacity and loss, sharply contrasted with robust health
posture: underscoring the extremity of their plight
instances.explanation: They portray themselves as like dead men in the presence of the ‘fat’ or sturdy, highlighting their utter powerlessness and loss.

deliberation: Checked the animal imagery. Found two explicit similes comparing their sounds of grief to bear growls and dove moans—distinct animal-voice images conveying the character of their lament.

instances.english_text: We all growl like bears
ground: bear growls are deep, harsh, and unsettling, mirroring intense human anguish
instances.explanation: Their cries under judgment are likened to the growls of bears, suggesting raw, harsh expressions of pain and frustration.

instances.english_text: And moan like doves
vehicle: the cooing or moaning of doves
ground: dove sounds evoke plaintive, mournful tones
posture: showing the pathos and helplessness of their grief
instances.explanation: Their lament is also compared to the moaning of doves, emphasizing the plaintive and mournful quality of their cries.

deliberation: Looked especially at courtroom imagery. The key figure is personification: their guilt ‘testifies’ against them as though it were a legal witness in court.

instances.english_text: Our guilt testifies against us
target: The evidential force of their sins before God
vehicle: a witness speaking or answering in court
ground: sins themselves function as undeniable evidence, as if they spoke against the sinner
posture: acknowledging the inescapable proof of their guilt
instances.explanation: Their sins are personified as a witness that ‘answers’ or testifies against them, casting their situation in forensic/judicial terms.

deliberation: Assessed idiomatic and spatial language. The notable figure is ‘turning away from following our God’—a spatial/path metaphor for apostasy, using physical movement as image for spiritual defection.

instances.english_text: And turning away from our God
vehicle: stepping back or withdrawing from following someone
ground: moving away physically pictures desertion and abandonment
posture: branding their behavior as deliberate desertion
instances.explanation: Apostasy is described as ‘withdrawing from after our God,’ using the common idiom of following/turning back to represent loyalty or its violation.

deliberation: Found multiple personifications: (1) justice and righteousness moving/standing at a distance; (2) truth stumbling in the street and uprightness barred from entry. These abstract qualities act as persons in public space.

instances.hebrew_text: וְהֻסַּג אָחוֹר מִשְׁפָּט וּצְדָקָה מֵרָחוֹק תַּעֲמֹד
instances.english_text: And so redress is turned back and vindication stays afar
target: The presence and operation of just judgment in society
vehicle: a person being pushed back and another standing far away
ground: being driven back or standing afar signifies exclusion and non-participation
instances.explanation: Justice and righteousness are personified as if they were people driven away and forced to stand far off, depicting their exclusion from public life.

instances.hebrew_text: כִּי־כָשְׁלָה בָרְחוֹב אֱמֶת וּנְכֹחָה לֹא־תוּכַל לָבוֹא
instances.english_text: Because honesty stumbles in the public square and uprightness cannot enter
target: Truthfulness and uprightness in the communal sphere
vehicle: a person stumbling in the street and another barred from entry
ground: stumbling denotes weakness and failure; inability to enter implies being shut out
posture: depicting public space as hostile to truth
instances.explanation: Truth is pictured as a person stumbling in the street, and uprightness as one who cannot gain entry, dramatizing how these virtues are excluded from public life.

deliberation: Checked for figurative expressions. The clause about one turning from evil becoming ‘prey’ uses hunting/predation imagery. Other elements are fairly literal descriptions of God’s seeing and displeasure.

instances.english_text: Whoever turns away from evil is despoiled / becomes prey
target: The treatment of those who reject evil
vehicle: prey that is despoiled or plundered
ground: being prey suggests vulnerability to attack and exploitation
posture: indicting a society where righteousness is punished
instances.explanation: The one who turns from evil is depicted as prey that is attacked or plundered, conveying how perverse the social order has become.

deliberation: Distinguished two main anthropomorphic/metaphorical clauses: (1) God’s ‘arm’ bringing salvation; (2) God’s ‘righteousness’ supporting him, like a prop. Both depict divine attributes as bodily or structural supports.

instances.english_text: Then God’s own arm did win triumph
ground: an arm performs powerful deeds and thus represents might
posture: highlighting God as sole effective savior
instances.explanation: God’s ‘arm’ stands metonymically and metaphorically for his powerful, saving action on behalf of his people.

instances.english_text: The victorious right hand gave support / his righteousness, it supported him
target: The inner basis and stability of God’s saving action
vehicle: a support or prop that holds someone up
ground: a support keeps one standing firm; righteousness functions as the inner strength of God’s acts
posture: portraying God’s righteousness as the sustaining force of salvation
instances.explanation: God’s righteousness is personified as a support that upholds him, a metaphor for his just character undergirding his saving work.

deliberation: The whole verse is a unitary armor/clothing metaphor: righteousness, salvation, vengeance, and zeal are cast as pieces of armor or garments that God dons. Treated as one extended metaphor rather than many separate micro-instances.

instances.hebrew_text: וַיִּלְבַּשׁ צְדָקָה כַּשִּׁרְיָן וְכֹובַע יְשׁוּעָה בְּרֹאשׁוֹ וַיִּלְבַּשׁ בִּגְדֵי נָקָם תִּלְבֹּשֶׁת וַיַּעַט כַּמְעִיל קִנְאָה
instances.english_text: [God] donned victory like a coat of mail, wearing a helmet of triumph—dressing in garments of retribution, wrapped in zeal like a robe.
target: God’s attributes and actions in judgment and salvation
vehicle: breastplate, helmet, garments, robe worn by a warrior
ground: armor equips for battle and expresses purpose; virtues like righteousness and zeal similarly equip God for judgment and deliverance
posture: depicting God as a divine warrior armed with his own moral qualities
instances.explanation: Righteousness, salvation, vengeance, and zeal are metaphorically portrayed as pieces of armor and clothing that YHWH puts on, casting him as a divine warrior whose ‘gear’ is his moral character.

deliberation: Language of repayment is largely literal judicial metaphor extended from legal to divine context; the main implicit figure is geographical metonymy: ‘coastlands/islands’ for the distant nations that will receive recompense.

instances.english_text: Requital to the distant lands (coastlands)
target: Distant peoples and nations opposed to God
ground: landed regions stand for their inhabitants or political communities
posture: asserting that even distant peoples will not escape judgment
instances.explanation: ‘Coastlands/islands’ functions as a metonymy for the far-off nations and their inhabitants, who will also receive divine recompense.

deliberation: Detected (1) a merism with west/east (‘from the west’ / ‘from the rising of the sun’) for universal scope, and (2) a simile/metaphor of God’s coming like a flood/river driven by YHWH’s wind, expressing overwhelming intervention.

instances.english_text: From the west, they shall revere GOD’s name, and from the east, the divine Presence
vehicle: west and east / setting and rising of the sun
opposite compass points and daily solar path
ground: mentioning opposite extremes implies the whole in between (merism)
sun’s path from east to west covers all directions
instances.explanation: ‘From the west’ and ‘from the rising of the sun’ form a merism, a rhetorical figure in which two extremes stand for the totality of the earth.

instances.hebrew_text: כִּי־יָבוֹא כַנָּהָר צָר רוּחַ יְהוָה נֹסְסָה בוֹ
instances.english_text: For [God] shall come like a hemmed-in stream that the wind of the ETERNAL drives on
target: God’s powerful, irresistible intervention in judgment or salvation
vehicle: a constrained river/flood driven forward by a strong wind
ground: a driven flood is unstoppable and sweeps all before it, mirroring the irresistible force of God’s coming
posture: portraying God’s intervention as overwhelming and unstoppable
instances.explanation: YHWH’s coming is likened to a river in constriction swept along by a divine wind, a simile-metaphor emphasizing the unstoppable, forceful character of his action.

deliberation: Examined whether ‘redeemer’ is purely metaphorical or covenant-legal language. The clearer figures here are geographical metonymies: ‘Zion’ and ‘Jacob’ standing for the people who inhabit/descend from them.

instances.hebrew_text: וּבָא לְצִיּוֹן גּוֹאֵל וּלְשָׁבֵי פֶשַׁע בְּיַעֲקֹב
instances.english_text: [God] shall come as redeemer to Zion, to those in Jacob who turn back from sin
target: The people of Jerusalem and Israel who repent
ground: the city/ancestor stands for the people associated with them
posture: emphasizing that the promised redemption is for the covenant people who repent
instances.explanation: ‘Zion’ and ‘Jacob’ function metonymically for their inhabitants/descendants—the people of Jerusalem and Israel who turn from transgression.

deliberation: Looked at Spirit ‘upon’ and words ‘in your mouth’. Treated especially ‘I have placed in your mouth’ as an idiomatic metaphor: God’s words as if physically put into the mouth, with ‘mouth’ a synecdoche for speech and proclamation.

instances.english_text: the words that I have placed in your mouth shall not be absent from your mouth
target: The prophet’s and community’s ongoing proclamation and internalization of God’s message
vehicle: putting something into a mouth and it not departing from the mouth
ground: placing in the mouth symbolizes giving and authorizing speech; non-departure signifies continual presence and use
posture: assuring the permanence of God’s word in the community
instances.explanation: God ‘putting’ words in the mouth is an idiomatic metaphor for endowing and commissioning speech, with ‘mouth’ metonymically representing speech itself.
